3 [[cruiser]]s | strength3 = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 =At least 37 dead and dozens wounded, with at least 14 of them dying in the following days. | notes = }} The '''5 October 1910 revolution''' was the overthrow of the centuries-old [[List of Portuguese monarchs|Portuguese Monarchy]] and its replacement by the [[Portuguese First Republic|Portuguese Republic]]. It was the result of a ''[[coup d'état]]'' organized by the [[Portuguese Republican Party]]. By 1910, the [[Kingdom of Portugal]] was in deep crisis: [[1890 British Ultimatum|British pressure on Portugal's colonies]],{{cite web|url=http://www.infopedia.pt/$implantacao-da-republica|title=Implantação da República |publisher=Infopédia|date=30 August 2010}} the royal family's expenses,{{cite web|url=http://avenidadaliberdade.org/index.php?content=1175&co_template=10|title=A Ditadura de João Franco e a autoria moral e política de D. Carlos|publisher=avenidadaliberdade.org|date=30 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119071242/http://avenidadaliberdade.org/index.php?content=1175&co_template=10|archivedate=19 January 2012|df=dmy-all}} the [[Lisbon Regicide|assassination of the King and his heir in 1908]], changing religious and social views, instability of the two political parties ([[Progressive Party (Portugal)|Progressive]] and [[Regenerator Party|Regenerador]]), the dictatorship of [[João Franco]],{{cite web|url=http://www.vidaslusofonas.pt/joaofranco.htm|title=João Franco|publisher=Vidas Lusófonas|date=30 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515101356/http://www.vidaslusofonas.pt/joaofranco.htm|archivedate=15 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} and the regime's apparent inability to adapt to modern times all led to widespread resentment against the Monarchy.{{cite web|url=http://www.cm-palmela.pt/NR/rdonlyres/2699A4EF-465D-4C5E-B8D7-C4544B81B2B0/39794/Escolas1Republica.pdf |title=1ª Republica – Dossier temático dirigido às Escolas |publisher=Rede Municipal de Bibliotecas Públicas do concelho de Palmela |date=30 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150423065653/http://www.cm-palmela.pt/NR/rdonlyres/2699A4EF-465D-4C5E-B8D7-C4544B81B2B0/39794/Escolas1Republica.pdf |archivedate=23 April 2015 |df=dmy }} The proponents of the republic, particularly the Republican Party, found ways to take advantage of the situation.{{cite web|url=http://in-devir.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=176&Itemid=37 |title=5 de Outubro de 1910: a trajectória do republicanismo |publisher=In-Devir |date=30 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622212517/http://in-devir.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=176&Itemid=37 |archivedate=22 June 2011 }} The Republican Party presented itself as the only one that had a programme that was capable of returning to the country its lost status and place Portugal on the way of progress.A este propósito ver {{Cite book|url= |first=Antero de |last=Quental |title=Prosas sócio-políticas ;publicadas e apresentadas por Joel Serrão |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisboa |publisher=Imprensa Nacional-Casa da Moeda |year=1982 |pages=248 |volume= |id=}} citado na secção "O Partido Republicano Português" deste artigo. After a reluctance of the military to combat the nearly two thousand soldiers and sailors that rebelled between 3 and 4 October 1910, the Republic was proclaimed at 9 o'clock of the next day from the balcony of the [[Lisbon City Hall|Paços do Concelho]] in Lisbon.{{cite web|url=http://www.leme.pt/biografias/portugal/presidentes/castro.html|title=Primeira República – Biografia de João de Canto e Castro|publisher=www.leme.pt|date=30 August 2010}} After the revolution, a provisional government led by [[Teófilo Braga]] directed the fate of the country until the approval of the Constitution in 1911 that marked the beginning of the First Republic.{{cite web|url=http://www.infopedia.pt/$constituicao-de-1911|title=Constituição de 1911 – Infopédia|publisher=www.infopedia.pt|date=9 September 2010}} Among other things, with the establishment of the republic, [[national symbol]]s were changed: the [[A Portuguesa|national anthem]] and the [[Flag of Portugal|flag]]. The revolution produced some [[civil rights|civil]] and [[Freedom of religion|religious liberties]], although there was no advance in [[women's rights]] and in [[workers rights]], unlike what happened in other European countries. ==Background== ===1890 British Ultimatum and 31 January rebellion=== {{Main|1890 British Ultimatum}} [[File:Mapa Cor-de-Rosa.svg|thumb|left|The ''[[Pink Map]]'' project: Portugal's claim of sovereignty over the lands between [[Portuguese Angola]] and [[Portuguese Mozambique]].]] On 11 January 1890 the British government of [[Lord Salisbury]] sent the Portuguese government an [[ultimatum]]{{cite web|url=http://www.soberaniadopovo.pt/portal/index.php?news=13083|title=Política: O Ultimato Inglês e o 31 de Janeiro de 1891|publisher=Soberania do Povo|accessdate=30 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://arquivo.pt/wayback/20140930205309/http://www.soberaniadopovo.pt/portal/index.php?news%3D13083|archivedate=30 September 2014|df=dmy-all}} in the form of a "memorandum", demanding the retreat of the Portuguese military forces led by [[Alexandre de Serpa Pinto|Serpa Pinto]] from the territory between the colonies of [[Portuguese Angola|Angola]] and [[Portuguese Mozambique|Mozambique]] (in the current [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Zambia]]), an area claimed by Portugal under the [[Pink Map]].{{cite web|url=http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_ultimatum.php|title=Ultimatum de 1890|publisher=Almanaque da República|accessdate=27 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230061833/http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_ultimatum.php|archivedate=30 December 2011|df=dmy-all}} The swift yielding by the Portuguese to the British demands was seen as a national humiliation by a broad cross-section of the population and the elite,{{cite web|url=http://www.infopedia.pt/$trinta-e-um-de-janeiro-de-1891|title=Trinta e Um de Janeiro de 1891 |publisher=Infopédia|accessdate=30 August 2010}} initiating a movement of deep dissatisfaction in relation with the new king, [[Carlos I of Portugal]], the royal family and the institution of the monarchy, which were seen as responsible for the alleged process of "national decline". The situation was aggravated by the severe financial crisis that occurred between 1890 and 1891, when the money sent from [[emigration|emigrants]] in Brazil decreased by 80% with the so-called [[Encilhamento|crisis of ''encilhamento'']] following the proclamation of the [[First Brazilian Republic|republic]] in Brazil two months previously, an event that was followed with apprehension by the monarchic government and with jubilation by the defenders of the republic in Portugal. The republicans knew how to take advantage of the dissatisfaction, initiating an increase of their social support base that would climax in the demise of the regime.{{cite web|author=Paulo Vicente |url=http://in-devir.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=176&Itemid=37 |title=O 5 de Outubro de 1910: a trajectória do republicanismo |publisher=In-Devir |accessdate=27 August 2010 |quote=O Partido Republicano [...] soube capitalizar em seu favor a crise económica que se abateu sobre o país e o descrédito em que se encontravam os partidos do rotativismo monárquico. Num tom violento e populista, desdobrava-se em violentas críticas ao rei e aos seus governos, que identificava com a "decadência nacional". Ao longo da década de 80 do século XIX, a expressão eleitoral do Partido Republicano foi crescendo e, com ela, cresceu também o clima de exaltação patriótica. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110622212517/http://in-devir.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=176&Itemid=37 |archivedate=22 June 2011 }} [[File:Rua 31 Janeiro (placa).JPG|thumb|right|Commemorative plaque on 31 de Janeiro Street, in [[Porto]].]] On 14 January, the progressive government fell and the leader of the Regenerador Party, [[António de Serpa Pimentel]], was chosen to form the new government.{{cite web|url=http://www.portugal.gov.pt/pt/GC18/Governo/ArquivoHistorico/ChefesGoverno/Pages/pms.aspx|title=Chefes do Governo desde 1821 |author=página do Governo da República Portuguesa|year=2009|accessdate=26 September 2010}} The progressivists then began to attack the king, voting for republican candidates in the March election of that year, questioning the colonial agreement then signed with the British. Feeding an atmosphere of near insurrection, on 23 March 1890, [[António José de Almeida]], at the time a student in the [[University of Coimbra]] and, later on, [[List of Presidents of Portugal|President of the Republic]], published an article entitled "''Bragança, o último''",{{cite web|url=http://www.presidencia.pt/?idc=13&idi=32|title=Antigos Presidentes: António José de Almeida|publisher=Página Oficial da Presidência da República Portuguesa|accessdate=30 August 2010}} considered slanderous against the king and led to Almeida's imprisonment. On 1 April 1890, the explorer [[António da Silva Porto|Silva Porto]] [[self-immolation|self-immolated]] wrapped in a Portuguese flag in [[Kuito]], Angola, after failed negotiations with the locals, under orders of [[Henrique Mitchell de Paiva Couceiro|Paiva Couceiro]], which he attributed to the ''ultimatum''. The death of the well-known explorer of the African continent generated a wave of national sentiment,{{cite book |first=Maria Emília Madeira |last=Santos |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=f4d4qtYuYQYC&lpg=PA27&dq=suic%C3%ADdio%20%22silva%20porto%22&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q=suic%C3%ADdio%20%22silva%20porto%22&f=false |title=Silva Porto e os problemas da África portuguesa no século XIX |work=Série Separatas / Centro de Estudos de Cartografia Antiga |language=Portuguese |location=Coimbra |publisher=Junta de Investigações Científicas do Ultramar |year=1983 |pages=27 |volume=149 }} and his funeral was followed by a crowd in Porto.{{cite web |author=KmMad |title=Silva Porto: do Brasil a África |language=Portuguese |url=http://km-stressnet.blogspot.com/2008/02/silva-porto-do-brasil-frica.html |accessdate=July 23, 2015}}{{cite book |first=René |last=Pélissier |title=Campanhas coloniais de Portugal, 1844–1941 |publisher=Estampa |year=2006 |pages=27 |isbn=9723323052 }} On 11 April, [[Guerra Junqueiro]]'s poetic work ''Finis Patriae'', a satire criticising the King, went on sale.{{cite web |url=http://analisesocial.ics.ul.pt/documentos/1223027734K4zTZ2wh1Lu94TC4.pdf |title=Política externa e política interna no Portugal de 1890: o Ultimatum Inglês |author=Nuno Severiano Teixeira |publisher=Análise Social – Instituto de Ciências Sociais da Universidade de Lisboa |accessdate=30 August 2010}} In the city of [[Porto]], on 31 January 1891, a military uprising against the [[monarchy]] took place, constituted mainly by [[sergeant]]s and [[enlisted rank]]s.{{cite web |url=http://pt.livra.com/item/a-revolta-de-31-de-janeiro-de-1891/65552803/ |title=A revolta de 31 de Janeiro de 1891 |publisher=Livra Portugal |accessdate=30 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110129075141/http://pt.livra.com/item/a-revolta-de-31-de-janeiro-de-1891/65552803/ |archivedate=29 January 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The rebels, who used the nationalist anthem ''[[A Portuguesa]]'' as their [[March (music)|marching song]], took the [[Seat of local government|Paços do Concelho]], from whose balcony, the republican journalist and politician [[Augusto Manuel Alves da Veiga]] proclaimed the establishment of the republic in Portugal and hoisted a red and green flag belonging to the Federal Democratic Centre. The movement was, shortly afterwards, suppressed by a military detachment of the municipal guard that remained loyal to the government, resulting in 40 injured and 12 casualties. The captured rebels were judged. 250 received sentences of between 18 months and 15 years of exile in Africa.{{cite web|url=http://www.faroldanossaterra.net/1891-revolta-militar-de-31-de-janeiro-no-porto/|title=1891: Revolta militar de 31 de Janeiro, no Porto|publisher=Farol da Nossa Terra|accessdate=30 August 2010}} ''A Portuguesa'' was forbidden. Despite its failure, the rebellion of 31 January 1891 was the first large threat felt by the monarchic regime and a sign of what would come almost two decades later.{{cite web |url=http://www.aventar.eu/2010/01/31/centenario-da-republica-31-de-janeiro |title=31 de Janeiro (Centenário da República) |accessdate=4 September 2010 |author=Carlos Loures |quote=O levantamento militar de 31 de Janeiro de 1891, no Porto, foi a primeira tentativa de derrube do regime monárquico pela força. Desde 1880, quando das comemorações do tricentenário de Camões, que, em crescendo, o ideal republicano e a capacidade de organização dos seus militantes, inclusive no seio das Forças Armadas, fazia prever uma rebelião. [...] Tendo fracassado no plano militar [...], o movimento de 31 de Janeiro foi, por assim dizer, uma vitória histórica, pois transformou-se numa data fetiche, num símbolo, para os republicanos que, dezanove anos depois triunfariam.}} ===The Portuguese Republican Party=== {{refimprove|section|date=October 2017}} {{Rquote|right|Thinking and science are republican, because creative genius lives on freedom and only a Republic can be truly free […]. Labour and industry are republican, because the creative activity wants security and stability and only a Republic […] is stable and secure […]. A Republic is, in the state, liberty […]; in industry, production; in labour, security; in the nation, strength and independence. For all, wealth; for all, equality; for all, light." |[[Antero de Quental]]|in ''República'', 11-05-1870{{cite book|url= |first=Antero de |last=Quental |title=Prosas sócio-políticas |work=publicadas e apresentadas por Joel Serrão |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisbon |publisher=Imprensa Nacional-Casa da Moeda |year=1982 |pages=248 |volume= |id=}}}} The revolutionary movement of 5 October 1910 occurred following the ideological and political action that, since its creation in 1876, the [[Portuguese Republican Party]] (PRP) had been developing with the objective of overthrowing the monarchic regime.{{cite web |author=Lourenço Pereira Coutinho |url=http://www.centenariodarepublica.org/centenario/2009/09/04/parte-i-%E2%80%93-os-primeiros-passos-da-fundacao-ao-centenario-de-camoes-187680/ |title=História do Partido Republicano Português – Parte I |publisher=Centenário da República – vamos fazer história! |accessdate=31 August 2010}} By making the national renewal dependent on the end of the monarchy, the Republican Party managed to define itself as distinct from the [[Portuguese Socialist Party]], which defended a collaboration with the regime in exchange for the rights of the working class and attracted the sympathy of the dissatisfied sections of society. Disagreements within the party became more connected with matters of political than ideological strategy. The ideological direction of the Portuguese republicanism had been traced much earlier by the works of [[José Félix Henriques Nogueira]], little changed through the years, except in terms of later adaptation to the everyday realities of the country. The works of [[Teófilo Braga]] contributed to this task by trying to concretise the decentralising and federalist ideas, abandoning the socialist quality in favour of democratic aspects. This change also aimed to attract the small and medium [[bourgeoisie]], which turned into one of the main bases of republican support. In the election of 13 October 1878 the PRP elected its first member of parliament, [[José Joaquim Rodrigues de Freitas]], for Porto.{{cite web |url=http://lagosdarepublica.wikidot.com/xv-rodrigues-de-freitas-primeiro-deputado-da-republica |title=Rodrigues de Freitas, Primeiro Deputado da República |accessdate=31 August 2010}} There was also an intention to give the overthrow of the monarchy overtones of unification, nationalism and being above the particular interests of individual social classes."''Ser republicano, por 1890, 1900 e 1910, queria dizer ser contra a Monarquia, contra a Igreja e os Jesuítas, contra a corrupção política e os partidos monárquicos. [...] A tendência geral era para se conceder à palavra República algo de carismático e místico, e para acreditar que bastaria a sua proclamação para libertar o País de toda a injustiça e de todos os males''". A. H. de Oliveira Marques (coord.). "Portugal – Da Monarquia para a República" in ''Nova História de Portugal'', Volume XI, Lisboa, Editorial Presença, 1991, p. 372. cit in Artur Ferreira Coimbra. ''[http://repositorium.sdum.uminho.pt/bitstream/1822/6989/1/Paiva%2520Couceiro%2520e%2520a%2520contra-revolu%25C3%25A7%25C3%25A3o.pdf Paiva Couceiro e a Contra-Revolução Monárquica (1910–1919)]''. Braga, Universidade do Minho, 2000. pp. 13–14. This [[panacea]] that would cure, once and for all, all the ills of the nation, elevating it to glory, emphasised two fundamental tendencies: nationalism and [[colonialism]]. From this combination came the final desertion of [[Iberian Federalism]], patent in the first republican theses by José Félix Henriques Nogueira,{{cite web|url=http://www.arqnet.pt/dicionario/nogueirajosefelixhenriques.html |title=Nogueira (José Félix Henriques) |publisher=Portugal – Dicionário Histórico |accessdate=31 August 2010}} identifying the monarchy as antipatriotism and the yielding to foreign interests. Another strong component of republican ideology was emphasised by [[anti-clericalism]],{{cite web|url=http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_igreja.php|title=Igreja e Estado|publisher=Almanaque da República|accessdate=27 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230100533/http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_igreja.php|archivedate=30 December 2011|df=dmy-all}} due to the theorisation of Teófilo Braga, who identified religion as an obstacle to progress and responsible for the scientific retardation of Portugal, in opposition to republicanism, which was linked by him to science, progress and well-being.Teófilo Braga, em carta escrita na sua juventude, prefigura já um implacável anticlericalismo: "''O padre há-de ser sempre uma sombra que se não dissipa nem à força de muita luz; envolve-nos, deixa-nos na solidão de nós mesmos, no tédio do vazio, quando a alegria transpira e ri lá fora por toda a parte; torna-nos pouco a pouco a vida um remorso, a esperança um nada impalpável, porque só no-la prometem para além da campa''" {{Cite book|url= |first=A. Carvalho |last=Homem |title=A Ideia Republicana em Portugal : o Contributo de Teófilo Braga |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Coimbra |publisher=Minerva |year=1989 |pages=172 |volume= |id=}} ''cit. in'' {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EPswrQxdZwsC&pg=PA28 |first=Alírio |last=Queirós |title=A Recepção de Freud em Portugal |work= |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Coimbra |publisher=Universidade de Coimbra |year=2009 |pages=28 |volume= |id=}} [[File:Comicio republicano em Lisboa.jpg|thumb|[[Eudóxio César Azedo Gneco]], also known as Azedo Gneco, one of the main leaders of the [[Portuguese Socialist Party]], giving a speech at a republican gathering in [[Lisbon]] (May 1, 1907)]] Ideological issues were not, ultimately, fundamental to the republican strategy: for the majority of sympathisers, who didn't even know the texts of the main manifestos, it was enough to be against the monarchy, against the Church and against the political corruption of traditional parties. This lack of ideological preoccupation doesn't mean that the party didn't bother to spread its principles. The most effective action of dissemination was the propaganda made through its rallies and popular demonstrations and bulletins such as ''A Voz Pública'' (The Public Voice) in Porto, ''O Século'' (The Age, from 1880) ''O Mundo'' (The World, from 1900) and ''A Luta'' (The Struggle, from 1906) in Lisbon. The republican propaganda managed to take advantage of some historical facts with popular repercussions. The celebrations of the third centenary of the death of [[Luís de Camões]] in 1580, and the British ''ultimatum'' in 1890, for example, were capitalised on to present the republicans as the true representatives of the purest national sentiments and popular aspirations. The third centenary of Camões was commemorated with great celebrations: a civic entourage that went through the streets of Lisbon, in the middle of great popular enthusiasm and, also, the transfer of the remains of Camões and [[Vasco da Gama]] to [[Jerónimos Monastery]].{{cite web |url=http://www.mosteirojeronimos.pt/pt/index.php?s=white&pid=227 |title=Vasco da Gama e Luís de Camões |accessdate=3 September 2010}} The atmosphere of the national celebration that characterised the commemorations complemented the patriotic exaltation. The idea of the Camões commemorations came from the [[Lisbon Geographic Society]], but the execution was entrusted to a commission constituted by, amongst others, Teófilo Braga, [[Ramalho Ortigão]], [[Jaime Batalha Reis]], Magalhães Lima and Pinheiro Chagas, leading figures of the Republican Party.{{cite web |url=http://www.instituto-camoes.pt/revista/percursmemo.htm |title=O tricentenário de Camões |accessdate=3 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514024334/http://www.instituto-camoes.pt/revista/percursmemo.htm |archivedate=14 May 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Besides Rodrigues de Freitas, [[Manuel de Arriaga]], José Elias Garcia, [[Zófimo Consiglieri Pedroso]], José Maria Latino Coelho, Bernardino Pereira Pinheiro, Eduardo de Abreu, Francisco Teixeira de Queirós, José Jacinto Nunes, and Francisco Gomes da Silva were also elected members of parliament, representing the PRP in various legislative sessions between 1884 and 1894. From this date to 1900 there was no republican parliamentary representation. In this phase, while separated from parliament, the party committed itself to its internal organisation. After a period of great repression of PRP, the republican movement could reenter the legislative race in 1900, electing four parliament members: [[Afonso Costa]], Alexandre Braga, [[António José de Almeida]] and João de Meneses. ===1908 Lisbon regicide=== {{Main|Lisbon Regicide}} [[file:L'attentat de Lisbonne.jpg|thumb| Anonymous reconstruction of the [[Lisbon Regicide|regicide]] published in the French press.]] On 1 February 1908, while returning to Lisbon from [[Vila Viçosa]] in [[Alentejo]], where they had spent the hunting season, the king [[Carlos I of Portugal|Carlos I]] and his heir the prince [[Luís Filipe, Prince Royal of Portugal|Luís Filipe]] were assassinated in Lisbon's [[Praça do Comércio|Commerce Square]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mundoportugues.org/content/1/2008/fevereiro-dia-que-monarquia-morreu/|title=1 de Fevereiro: O dia em que a Monarquia morreu|publisher=Mundo Portugues|accessdate=30 August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828171104/http://www.mundoportugues.org/content/1/2008/fevereiro-dia-que-monarquia-morreu/|archive-date=28 August 2008|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The attack occurred after a progressive decline of the Portuguese political system, effective since the [[Regeneration (Portugal)|Regeneration]],{{cite web|url=http://blx.cm-lisboa.pt/gca/index.php?id=914 |title=Quais os motivos que estão na base do regicídio?|publisher=Departamento de Bibliotecas e Arquivos, da Câmara Municipal de Lisboa|accessdate=30 August 2010}} due in part by the political erosion originated from the system of rotating governments (which saw the Progressive Party and Regenerator Party alternating in government). The king, as arbiter of the system, a role attributed to him by the Constitution, had designated [[João Franco]] as the president of the Council of Ministers (government chief).{{cite web|url=http://www.arqnet.pt/dicionario/francojoao.html|title=João Franco|publisher=Portugal – Dicionário Histórico|accessdate=30 August 2010}} João Franco, dissident of the Regenerator Party, convinced the king to dissolve the parliament so that he could implement a series of measures with the aim to moralise Portuguese politics.{{cite web|url=http://www.iscsp.utl.pt/~cepp/governos_portugueses/1900-1910/joao_franco.htm|title=Governo de João Franco|publisher=www.iscsp.utl.pt|accessdate=30 August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110302233215/http://www.iscsp.utl.pt/~cepp/governos_portugueses/1900-1910/joao_franco.htm|archive-date=2 March 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} This decision irritated not only the republican but also the monarchical opposition, led by political rivals of Franco who accused him of governing in dictatorship. The events were aggravated by the issues of the advanced payments to the Royal House and the signing of the decree of 30 January 1908 that foresaw the banishment to the colonies, without judgement, of those involved in a failed republican coup occurred two days previously, the [[Municipal Library Elevator Coup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=193330|title=Do visconde de esgrima, as armas que mataram o rei...|publisher=A Bola|accessdate=30 August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807141858/http://abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=193330|archive-date=7 August 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} {{Rquote|left|I saw a man with a black beard […] open a cape and take out a carbine […]. When I saw [him] […] aiming at the carriage I realised, unfortunately, what it was. My God, the horror of what then happened! Soon after Buíça opened fire […] started a perfect shooting, like a fight among beasts. The Palace Square was deserted, not a soul! This is what I find hardest to forgive João Franco… |D. Manuel II{{cite web|author=D. Manuel II |url=http://www.laicidade.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/01/relato-manuel-ii-01.pdf |title=O Atentado de 1 de Fevereiro. Documentos |publisher=Associação Cívica República e Laicidade, pp. 3 e 4 |accessdate=27 August 2010}}}} The Royal Family was in the [[Ducal Palace of Vila Viçosa]], but the events led the king to bring forward his return to Lisbon, taking a train from the station of Vila Viçosa on the morning of 1 February. The royal escort arrived in [[Barreiro Municipality|Barreiro]] in the evening where, to cross the [[Tagus]], it took a steam boat to Terreiro do Paço in Lisbon, at around 5pm.{{cite web|url=http://hemerotecadigital.cm-lisboa.pt/EFEMERIDES/Regicidio/Percurso.htm|title=Percurso histórico do Regicídio|publisher=Hemeroteca Digital|accessdate=30 August 2010}} Despite the atmosphere of great tension, the king chose to continue in an open [[carriage]], with a reduced escort, to demonstrate normality. While greeting the crowds present in the square, the carriage was struck by several shots. One of the [[carbine]] bullets hit the king's neck, killing him immediately. More shooting followed, and the [[Prince Royal of Portugal|prince]] was hit by another shot. The queen defended herself with the bouquet of flowers offered by the people, which she used to hit one of the attackers who had climbed onto the carriage. The prince D. Manuel was also struck on an arm. Two of the attackers, [[Manuel Buíça]], primary school teacher, and [[Alfredo Luís da Costa]], commerce employee and editor, were killed in the scene. Others managed to escape. The carriage entered the Navy Arsenal, where the deaths of the king and his heir were verified. After the attack, João Franco's government was dismissed and a rigorous investigation was launched which found, two years later, that the attack had been committed by members of the secret organisation ''[[Carbonária]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.g-sat.net/g-sat-historia-1643/4-dinastia-d-carlos-o-martirizado-reinou-de-1889-a-1908-a-94641.html|title=4ª Dinastia D. Carlos – o "Martirizado" reinou de 1889 – a 1908|publisher=www.g-sat.net|accessdate=30 August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130920154309/http://www.g-sat.net/g-sat-historia-1643/4-dinastia-d-carlos-o-martirizado-reinou-de-1889-a-1908-a-94641.html|archive-date=20 September 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} The investigation process finished on 5 October 1910. However, more suspects were subsequently found to have direct involvement, some of whom had gone into hiding in [[First Brazilian Republic|Brazil]] and [[French Third Republic|France]] and at least two had been killed by the ''Carbonária'' itself.{{cite web|url=http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_regicidio_1908.php|title=Regicídio no Terreiro do Paço|publisher=Almanaque da República|accessdate=27 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101207060627/http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_regicidio_1908.php|archivedate=7 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} Europe was shocked by the attack, since King Carlos was highly regarded by other European heads of state."O atentado horrorizará a Europa e o mundo. O facto de não ser um acto isolado de um anarquista ou de um par de fanáticos, mas um conluio organizado, chocará particularmente a comunidade internacional. Imagens das campas dos regicidas cobertas de flores são publicadas na imprensa inglesa com o título "Lisbon's Shame" (A vergonha de Lisboa)." In NOBRE, Eduardo. "O regicídio de 1908" in revista ''Única'', 2004, p. 40. The Lisbon regicide hastened the end of the monarchy by placing D. Manuel II on the throne and throwing the monarchical parties against one another. ===The agony of the monarchy=== {{Rquote|right|Their [the republicans'] shows of strength on the streets of Lisbon – for example, on 2 August 1909, which brought together fifty thousand people, with an impressive discipline – echo the riots organised in the Assembly by some republican Parliament representatives. It was on the night of 2 August that I understood that the crown was at stake: when the king, rightly or wrongly, is contested or rejected by a part of the opinion, he can no longer fulfil his unifying role. |[[Amélie of Orléans]]{{cite book|url= |first=Stéphane |last=Bern |title=Eu, Amélia, Última Rainha de Portugal |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Porto |publisher=Livraria Civilização Editora |year=1999 |pages=172 |volume= |id=}}}} Due to his young age (18 years) and the tragic and bloody way in which he reached power, [[Manuel II of Portugal]] obtained an initial sympathy from the public.{{cite book|first=Maria Cândida |last=Proença |title=D. Manuel II: Colecção "Reis de Portugal" |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisboa |publisher=Círculo de Leitores |year=2006 |pages=100 |volume= |id=}} The young king began his rule by nominating a consensus government presided by admiral [[Francisco Joaquim Ferreira do Amaral]]. This government of ''pacification'', as it became known, despite achieving a temporary calm, only lasted for a short amount of time.{{cite book|url= |first=José Hermano |last=Saraiva |title=História de Portugal |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisboa |publisher=Publicações Alfa |year=1983 |pages=112 |volume=6 |id=}}. The political situation degraded again quickly, leading to having seven different governments in the space of two years. The monarchical parties rose against each other once more and fragmented into splinter groups, while the Republican Party continued to gain ground. In the election of 5 April 1908, the last legislative elections to occur during the monarchy, seven members were elected to parliament, among which were Estêvão de Vasconcelos, Feio Terenas and [[Manuel de Brito Camacho]]. In the election of 28 August 1910 the party had a resounding success, electing 14 members to parliament, 10 for Lisbon.{{cite web|url=http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_governo.php|title=Governo de Acalmação|publisher=Almanaque da República|accessdate=27 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110508022850/http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_governo.php|archivedate=8 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} Meanwhile, in spite of the evident electoral success of the republican movement, the most revolutionary sector of the party called for armed struggle as the best means to achieve power in a short amount of time. It was this faction that came victorious from the party congress that took place in [[Setúbal]] between the 23 and 25 April 1909.{{cite web |url=http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_setubal.php |title=Congresso republicano |publisher=Almanaque da República |accessdate=27 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230103519/http://www.republica2010.com/datas/datas_setubal.php |archivedate=30 December 2011 |df=dmy-all }} The directorate, composed by the moderate [[Teófilo Braga]], [[Basílio Teles]], [[Eusébio Leão]], José Cupertino Ribeiro and [[José Relvas]], received from the congress the imperative mandate to ''start the revolution''. The logistic role for the preparation of plot was assigned to the most radical elements. The civil committee was formed by [[Afonso Costa]], [[João Pinheiro Chagas]] and [[António José de Almeida]], while the admiral [[Carlos Cândido dos Reis]] was the leader of the military committee.{{cite web |url=http://www.republica2010.com/figuras/figuras_candido_reis.php |title=Cândido dos Reis |publisher=Almanaque da República |accessdate=27 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904194533/http://www.republica2010.com/figuras/figuras_candido_reis.php |archivedate=4 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }} António José de Almeida was assigned the role of organising the secret societies such as the ''Carbonária'' – in whose leadership was integrated the naval commissary [[António Machado Santos]]{{cite web |url=http://www.republica2010.com/instituicoes/instituicoes_carbonaria.php |title=Instituições – Carbonária |publisher=Almanaque da República |accessdate=27 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100929062623/http://www.republica2010.com/instituicoes/instituicoes_carbonaria.php |archivedate=29 September 2010 |df=dmy-all }} —, the [[Freemasonry|freemasons]] and the ''Junta Liberal'', led by [[Miguel Bombarda]]. This eminent doctor played an important part in the dissemination of republican propaganda among the bourgeoisie, which brought many sympathisers to the republican cause.{{cite web|url=http://www.republica2010.com/figuras/figuras_bombarda.php |title=Miguel Bombarda |publisher=Almanaque da República |accessdate=17 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904194528/http://www.republica2010.com/figuras/figuras_bombarda.php |archivedate=4 September 2010 }} The period between the congress of 1909 and the emergence of the revolution was marked by great instability and political and social unrest,{{cite web|url=http://www.republica2010.com/instituicoes/instituicoes_monarquia.php |title=Instituições – Monarquia terminal |publisher=Almanaque da República |accessdate=17 December 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120132606/http://www.republica2010.com/instituicoes/instituicoes_monarquia.php |archivedate=20 January 2012 }} with several threats of uprising risking the revolution due to the impatience of the [[Portuguese Navy|navy]], led by [[António Machado Santos|Machado Santos]], who was ready for action. ==The uprising== On 3 October 1910 the republican uprising foreshadowed by the political unrest finally took place.{{cite web|url=http://www.citi.pt/cultura/historia/personalidades/afonso_costa/5outub3.html|title=Afonso Costa – 5 de Outubro de 1910|publisher=www.citi.pt|accessdate=31 August 2010}} Although many of those involved in the republican cause avoided participation in the uprising, making it seem like the revolt had failed, it eventually succeeded thanks to the government's inability to gather enough troops to control the nearly two hundred armed revolutionaries that resisted in the [[Marquess of Pombal Square|Rotunda]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prof2000.pt/users/jdsa03/olho/0405/1p04/5_de_outubro.htm |title=5 de Outubro de 1910|publisher=Olho Vivo|accessdate=31 August 2010}} ===Movements of the first revolutionaries=== [[File:Teixeira de Sousa.jpg|thumb|Prime Minister [[António Teixeira de Sousa|Teixeira de Sousa]]]] In summer of 1910 Lisbon was teeming with rumours and many times the President of the Council of Ministers (Prime Minister) [[António Teixeira de Sousa|Teixeira de Sousa]] was warned of imminent ''coups d'état''.{{cite web|url=http://www.tintafresca.net/News/newsdetail.aspx?news=9ee73416-1a30-444e-be33-df582d159b89&edition=60|title=A revolução do 5 de Outubro de 1910 |publisher=Tinta Fresca|accessdate=31 August 2010}} The revolution was not an exception: the ''coup'' was expected by the government,{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00615|title=Assassinato de Miguel Bombarda|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=31 August 2010}} who on 3 October gave orders for all the garrison troops of the city to be on guard. After a dinner offered in honour of D. Manuel II by [[President of Brazil|Brazilian president]] [[Hermes da Fonseca]], then on a state visit to Portugal,{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=034854|title=Visita a Portugal do Presidente da República do Brasil, Marechal Hermes da Fonseca|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=31 August 2010}} the monarch retreated to the [[Palace of Necessidades]] while his uncle and sworn heir to the throne, prince [[Afonso, Prince Royal of Portugal|D. Afonso]], went on to the Citadel of [[Cascais]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00635|title=D. Manuel de Bragança parte para o exílio|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=31 August 2010}} After the murder of [[Miguel Bombarda]], shot by one of his patients,{{cite web|url=http://www.centenariorepublica.pt/escolas/cronologia-5-outubro-1910/3%20Out.|title=O 5 de Outubro de 1910. Dia 3 Out.|publisher=Centenário da República|accessdate=31 August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090925172820/http://www.centenariorepublica.pt/escolas/cronologia-5-outubro-1910/3%20Out.|archive-date=25 September 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} the republican leaders assembled with urgency on the night of the 3rd.{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=040981|title=Quartel-general nos Banhos de S. Paulo|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=31 August 2010}} Some officials were against the meeting due to the strong military presence, but Admiral Cândido dos Reis insisted for it to take place, saying "''A Revolução não será adiada: sigam-me, se quiserem. Havendo um só que cumpra o seu dever, esse único serei eu.''" ("The Revolution will not be delayed: follow me, if you want. If there is one that fulfills their duty, this one will be me.").{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=034855|title=Reunião da Rua da Esperança|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=31 August 2010}}{{cite book|url= |first=José |last=Relvas |title=Memórias Políticas |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisboa |publisher=Terra Livre |year=1977 |page=112 |volume= |id=}} [[File:Revoltosos nas barricadas rotunda 5 de outubro.jpg|thumb|left|Rebels congregate on [[Marquess of Pombal Square|Rotunda Square]].]] [[António Machado Santos|Machado Santos]] had already got into action and did not attend the assembly. Instead, he went to the military quarters of the 16th Infantry Regiment{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=040980|title=Machado Santos prepara o assalto a Infantaria 16|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=31 August 2010}} where a revolutionary corporal had triggered a rebellion involving the majority of the garrison. A commander and a captain were killed when they made an attempt to control it. Entering a barracks with dozens of members of the ''Carbonária'', the naval officer went on with about 100 soldiers that entered the 1st Artillery Regiment,{{cite book |last=Medina |first=João |date=2004 |title=História de Portugal |chapter=Monarquia Constitucional (II) – A República (I) |language=Portuguese |publisher=Edita Ediclube, Edição e Promoção do Livro |location=Amadora |isbn=9789727192694 |volume=XX, XII |page=445}} where Captain Afonso Palla and a few sergeants and civilians, had already taken the administration building and captured all officers that refused to join them."Quartel de Compolide" in [http://revelarlx.cm-lisboa.pt/fotos/gca/1263999267painel_conspiracao_entradas.pdf Da Conspiração ao 5 de Outubro de 1910] With the arrival of Machado Santos two columns were formed which were placed under the leadership of captains Sá Cardoso and Palla. The first went to meet the 2nd Infantry Regiment and the 2nd ''[[Caçadores]]'' Regiment, also sympathisers of the rebellion, to go on to [[Alcântara (Lisbon)|Alcântara]] where it was to support the naval barracks. The original route intersected with a Municipal Guard outpost which forced the column to follow a different route. After a few confrontations with the police and civilians, it finally found the column led by Palla. Together, the columns advanced to Rotunda, where they entrenched at around 5am. The stationed force was composed of around 200 to 300 men of the 1st Artillery Regiment, 50 to 60 men of the 16th Infantry Regiment and around 200 civilians. The captains Sá Cardoso and Palla and the naval commissary Machado Santos were among the 9 officers in command. Meanwhile, Lieutenant Ladislau Parreira and some officers and civilians entered the barracks of the Naval Corps of Alcântara at 1am, managing to take arms, provoke a revolt and capture the commanders, one of whom was wounded.{{cite web |url=http://www.centenariorepublica.pt/escolas/cronologia-5-outubro-1910/4%20Out. |title=O 5 de Outubro de 1910. Dia 4 Out. |publisher=Comissão Nacional para as Comemorações do Centenário da República |accessdate=31 August 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925180523/http://centenariorepublica.pt/escolas/cronologia-5-outubro-1910/4%20Out. |archive-date=25 September 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The aim of this action was to prevent the exit of the cavalry unit of the Municipal Guard, an aim that was achieved."Quartel do Corpo de Marinheiros de Alcântara" in [http://revelarlx.cm-lisboa.pt/fotos/gca/1263999267painel_conspiracao_entradas.pdf Da Conspiração ao 5 de Outubro de 1910] For this end, they required the support of 3 warships anchored in the Tagus. By this time, Lieutenant [[José Mendes Cabeçadas|Mendes Cabeçadas]] had already taken command of the mutinied crew of the ''[[NRP Adamastor]]''{{Cite web | title = ANTIGOS PRESIDENTES: Mendes Cabeçadas – Página Oficial da Presidência da República Portuguesa | accessdate = 8 September 2010 | url = http://www.presidencia.pt/?idc=13&idi=30 }} while the mutinied crew of the ''São Rafael'' waited for an officer to command it. At about 7am Ladislau Parreira, having been informed by civilians of the situation, sent the Second-Lieutenant Tito de Morais to take command of the ''São Rafael'', with orders for both ships to support the garrison of the barracks. When it became known that on the ship ''D. Carlos I'' the crew had begun a mutiny but the officers had entrenched, Lieutenant Carlos da Maia and a few sailors left the ''São Rafael''. After some gunfire from which a lieutenant and a ship commander became wounded, the officers gave up control of the ''D. Carlos I'', yielding it to the hands of the republicans. [[File:Cruzador D. Carlos I.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|Portuguese cruiser ''Dom Carlos I'' painted by [[Giovanni Battista Castagneto]]]] That was the last unit to join the rebels, which included by then part of the 1st Artillery Regiment, 16th Infantry Regiment, the naval corps and the three warships. Navy members had joined in large numbers as expected, but many military sections considered sympathizers with the cause hadn't joined. Even so, the republican forces included about 400 men in Rotunda, 1000 to 1500 in Alcântara counting the naval crews, as well as having managed to take hold of the city's artillery, with most of the ammunition, to which was added the naval artillery. Rotunda and Alcântara were occupied, but concrete plans for the revolution had not yet been decided and the main leaders hadn't yet appeared. In spite of this, the beginning of the events did not occur favorably for the rebels. The three cannon shots – the accorded signal for the civilians and military to advance – did not take place. Only a shot was heard and the Admiral Cândido dos Reis, expecting the signal to take command of the warships, was informed that everything had failed, which prompted him to retire to his sister's house. The next morning his dead body was found in [[São Jorge de Arroios (Lisbon)|Arroios]]. In desperation, he had committed suicide by a shot to the head. Meanwhile, in Rotunda, the apparent calm in the city was so discouraging to the rebels that officers preferred to give up. Sá Cardoso, Palla and other officers retired to their houses, but Machado Santos stayed and assumed command. This decision proved fundamental to the success of the revolution. ===The government forces=== The military garrison of Lisbon was composed by four [[infantry]] regiments, two [[cavalry]] regiments and two [[Caçadores|light infantry]] [[battalions]], with a theoretical total of 6982 men. However, in practice, there were other useful units in military outposts used for lookout and general police duties, especially in the industrial district of [[Barreiro Municipality|Barreiro]] due to the bout of strikes and syndicalist activity that had been ongoing since September .{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00612 |title=Alastra o surto de greves |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=1 September 2010}} Ever since the previous year the government forces had a plan of action, drawn up by order of the military commander of Lisbon, General Manuel Rafael Gorjão Henriques. When, on the evening of the 3rd, the President of the Council of Ministers [[António Teixeira de Sousa|Teixeira de Sousa]] informed him of the imminence of a revolt, a prevention order was soon sent to the garrisons in the city. The units of Artillery 3 and Light Infantry 6 were called from [[Santarém, Portugal|Santarém]], while Infantry 15 was called from [[Tomar]]. As soon as news of the revolt was received, the plan was put into practice: the 1st Infantry, 2nd Infantry, 2nd Light Infantry and 2nd Cavalry regiments and the [[artillery battery]] of [[Queluz, Portugal|Queluz]], went to the [[Palace of Necessidades]] to protect the king, while Infantry 5 and Light Infantry 5 moved to [[Rossio Square]], with the mission to protect the military headquarters. As for the police force and municipal guards, they were distributed through the city as set out in the plan, intended to protect strategic points such as [[Rossio Railway Station]], the gas factory, the Portuguese [[Imprensa Nacional-Casa da Moeda|mint]], the postal building, the [[Carmo Convent (Lisbon)|Carmo barracks]], the ammunition depot in Beirolas and the residence of the President of the Council of Ministers, where the government had assembled. Little is known of the Fiscal Guard (a total of 1397 men), only that a few soldiers were with the troops in Rossio. The civil police (total of 1200 men) stayed in the squads. This inaction decreased the effective government forces by approximately 2600 men.David Ferreira, "Outubro de 1910, 5 de" in Joel Serrão (dir.) ''Dicionário de História de Portugal''. Porto, Livraria Figueirinhas, 1985, vol. IV, pp. 500–504 ===The fighting=== [[File:Revoltosos nas barricadas mulheres e homens 5 de outubro.jpg|thumb|left|Rebels of the Carbonária on Rotunda square.]] The fact that some units of the monarchical side sympathised with the republicans, combined with the abandonment by the rebels of the original plan of action, opting instead for entrenchment in [[Marquess of Pombal Square|Rotunda]] and [[Alcântara (Lisbon)|Alcântara]], led to a situation of impasse throughout 4 October, with all manner of rumours about victories and defeats spreading through the city. As soon as news of the concentration of rebels in Rotunda were received, the military command of the city organised a detachment to break them up. The column, under the command of Colonel Alfredo Albuquerque, was formed by units that had been removed from the protection of the Palace of Necessidades: Infantry 2, Cavalry 2 and the mobile battery of Queluz. The latter included the colonial war hero [[Henrique Mitchell de Paiva Couceiro]]. The column advanced until near the prison, where it assumed combat positions. However, before these were completed, the column was attacked by rebels. The attack was repelled but resulted in a few wounded men, several dead pack animals and the scattering of about half the infantry. Paiva Couceiro responded with cannons and the infantry that remained during 45 minutes, ordering an attack that was carried out by around 30 soldiers, but which was beaten with some casualties. Continuing the gunfire, he ordered a new attack, but only 20 soldiers followed the order. Thinking that he had found the right time to assault the barracks of Artillery 1, Paiva Couceiro requested reinforcement to the division's command. However, he received the perplexing order to retreat.{{cite web |url=http://jornal.publico.pt/noticia/20-08-2010/a-revolucao-no-seu-dia-inicial-19922945.htm |ligação inativa= |title=República: A revolução no seu "dia inicial" |accessdate=5 September 2010 |author=Amadeu Carvalho Homem |work=Público }} [[File:Brazilian battleship São Paulo trials.jpg|thumb|While in transit through Lisboa, the Brazilian president [[Hermes da Fonseca]] witnessed the revolution from the {{ship|Brazilian battleship|São Paulo}} (pictured).]] Meanwhile, a column had been formed with the intention to attack simultaneously the rebels in Rotunda, a plan that was never carried out because of the order to retreat. The column reached Rossio in the evening without having joined combat. This inaction was not caused by the incompetence of its commander, General António Carvalhal, as would become clear the next day, when he was named chief of the Military Division for the republican government: he had changed sides. Reinforcements from other parts of the country, expected by the government throughout 4 October, never arrived. Only the units already mentioned and called for the preventive measures received orders to advance. Since the beginning of the revolution, members of the ''Carbonária'' had disconnected the [[telegraph]] lines, thus cutting communication with units outside Lisbon. In addition, the rebels had cut off the [[Track (rail transport)|railway tracks]],{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00633|title=Paiva Couceiro bombardeia a Rotunda e a Armada anuncia desembarque |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=15 September 2010}} which meant that even if the troops followed the orders to advance on Lisbon, they would never arrive on time. Reinforcements from the [[Península de Setúbal Subregion|Setúbal peninsula]] were also unlikely to arrive, since the [[Tagus|Tagus river]] was controlled by rebel ships.{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=034858 |title=Cruzador D. Carlos passa-se para os republicanos |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=22 September 2010}} Towards the end of the day the situation was difficult for the monarchical forces: the rebel ships were docked beside the [[Praça do Comércio|Palace Square]] and the cruiser ''São Rafael'' opened fire on the ministry buildings{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=034857 |title=Armada bombardeia o Rossio |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=22 September 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00622 |title=Cruzadores S. Rafael e Adamastor bombardeiam o Palácio das Necessidades |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=22 September 2010}} in the bewildered sight of the Brazilian diplomatic corps aboard [[Brazilian battleship São Paulo|battleship ''São Paulo'']], whose passenger list included the elected president [[Hermes da Fonseca]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=034854 |title=Visita a Portugal do Presidente da República do Brasil, Marechal Hermes da Fonseca |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=22 September 2010}} This attack undermined the morale of the pro-government forces in Rossio. ===The king's departure from Lisbon=== [[File:Manuel II.jpg|thumb|left|King [[Manuel II of Portugal]]]] After the dinner with Hermes da Fonseca, [[Manuel II of Portugal|D. Manuel II]] had returned to the [[Palace of Necessidades]], keeping the company of a few officers. They were playing [[Contract bridge|bridge]]{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=040984|title=O rei foge para Mafra|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=1 September 2010}} when the rebels began an attack on the building.{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=040983|title=Ordem para o bombardeamento do Palácio das Necessidade|publisher=Fundação Mário Soares|accessdate=1 September 2010}} The king attempted some phone calls but, finding that the lines had been cut, managed only to inform the [[Amélie of Orléans|Queen Mother]], who was in [[Pena National Palace]], about the situation. Soon afterwards, groups of units that were loyal to the king arrived at the scene and managed to defeat the attacks of the revolutionaries. At 9 o'clock the king received a phone call from the president of the Council, advising him to find refuge in [[Mafra, Portugal|Mafra]] or [[Sintra]], since the rebels were threatening to bomb the Palace of Necessidades. D.Manuel II refused to leave, saying to those present: "Go if you want, I'm staying. Since the constitution doesn't appoint me any role other than of letting myself be killed, I will abide by it."{{cite book|url= |first=Rocha |last=Martins |title=D. Manuel II: História do seu Reinado e da Implantação da República |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisbon |publisher=edição do autor |year=1931–1933 |pages=521 |volume= |id=}} With the arrival of the mobile battery from [[Queluz, Portugal|Queluz]], the pieces were arranged in the palace gardens so that they could bombard the quarters of the revolutionary sailors, which were located at no more than 100 metres from the palace. However, before they had time to start, the commander of the battery received the order to cancel the bombing and join the forces that were leaving the palace, integrated into the column that would attack the rebel forces of Artillery 1 in the Rotunda. At around midday the cruisers ''Adamastor'' and ''São Rafael'', which had anchored in front of the sailors' quarters, started the bombardment of the Palace of Necessidades, an action which served to demoralise the present monarchical forces. The king took refuge in a small house in the palace's park, where he could ring Teixeira de Sousa, since the revolutionaries had only cut the special state telephone lines and not the general network. The king ordered the prime minister to send the battery from Queluz to the palace to prevent a naval landing, but the prime minister replied that the main action was happening in Rotunda and all the troops that were there were needed. Taking into account that the available troops were not sufficient to defeat the rebels in Rotunda, the prime minister made it obvious to the king that it would be more convenient to retire to Sintra or Mafra so that the stationed forces of the palace could reinforce the troops in Rotunda. At two o'clock the vehicles with D. Manuel II and his advisors set out to Mafra, where the Infantry School would provide enough forces to protect the monarch. While approaching [[Benfica (Lisbon)|Benfica]] the king dismissed the municipal guard squad that escorted him so that they could join the fight against the rebels. The escort arrived in Mafra at around four o'clock in the afternoon, but then discovered a problem: due to the holidays, the Infantry School contained only 100 soldiers, as opposed to the 800 that were expected, and the person in charge, Colonel Pinto da Rocha, admitted to not having the means to protect the king.{{cite book|url= |first=Pedro Soares |last=Martínez |title=A República Portuguesa e as Relações Internacionais (1910–1926) |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisbon |publisher=Verbo |year=2001 |pages=40–41 |volume= |isbn=9722220349}} In the meantime, Counsellor João de Azevedo Coutinho arrived and advised the king to call to Mafra the queens [[Amélie of Orléans|D. Amélia]] and [[Maria Pia of Savoy|D. Maria Pia]] (respectively, the king's mother and grandmother), who were in the palaces of [[Pena National Palace|Pena]] and [[Sintra National Palace|Vila]] in [[Sintra]], and to prepare to continue on to [[Porto]], where they would organise a resistance. In Lisbon, the king's departure did not bring a large advantage to the government since the majority of the troops now available to engage the rebel forces did not follow the orders to march to [[Rossio Square]] to prevent the concentration of rebel artillery in [[Alcântara (Lisbon)|Alcântara]]. ===The triumph of the revolution=== [[File:Revoltosos nas barricadas marcha com a bandeira da carbonaria.jpg|thumb|Rebels march with the Carbonária flag on [[Marquess of Pombal Square|Rotunda Square]] on 5 October 1910.]] [[File:Proclamação República Portuguesa.jpg|thumb|Proclamation of the Portuguese Republic by [[José Relvas]]]] [[File:Auto da Proclamação da República Portuguesa.png|thumb|Auto Proclamation of the Portuguese Republic]] On the night of 4 October morale was low amongst the monarchical troops stationed in [[Rossio Square]], due to the constant danger of being bombarded by the naval forces and not even Couceiro's batteries, strategically placed there, could bring them comfort. In the headquarters there were discussions about the best position to bomb the Rotunda. At 3am, Paiva Couceiro departed with a mobile battery, escorted by a municipal guard squad, and positioned himself in Castro Guimarães Garden, in Torel, waiting for daybreak. When the forces in Rotunda began to fire on Rossio, revealing their position, Paiva Couceiro opened fire, causing casualties and sowing confusion amongst the rebels. The bombardment continued with advantage towards the monarchical side, but at eight in the morning Paiva Couceiro received orders to stop fighting, as there would be an [[armistice]] of an hour.{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00620 |title=A noite de 4 para 5 de Outubro |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=1 September 2010}} Meanwhile, in Rossio, after Paiva de Couceiro's departure with the battery, the morale of the monarchical troops, which considered themselves helpless, deteriorated even more due to the threats of bombardment by the naval forces.{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=034857 |title=Armada bombardeia o Rossio |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=1 September 2010}} Infantry 5 and some members of Light Infantry 5 insisted that they would not oppose a naval landing. Confronted with this fraternisation with the enemy, the commanders of these formations went to the headquarters, where they were surprised with the news of the armistice. {{Rquote|left|Proclaimed by major military forces, all armed and aided by the popular contest, the Republic now has its first day of History. The unfolding of the events, by the time of writing, can feed all hope for a definite triumph. […] It's hard to imagine the enthusiasm that runs through the city. The people are truly crazy with satisfaction. It could be said that the entire population of Lisbon is on the streets, cheering the republic. |''O Mundo'', 5 October 1910{{cite web|url=http://capimmargoso.blogspot.com/2009/10/historia-noticias-da-proclamacao-da.html |title=Notícias da Proclamação da República em Portugal |publisher=Capim Margoso |accessdate=1 September 2010}}}} The new German representative, who had arrived two days earlier, had taken rooms in Hotel Avenida Palace, which housed many foreigners. The proximity of the building to the combat zone represented a great danger which prompted the diplomat to intervene. He addressed himself to the General Gorjão Henriques to request a cease-fire that would enable him to evacuate foreign citizens. Without notifying the government, and perhaps hoping to buy time for the arrival of the reinforcements, the general agreed.{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=034862 |title=Encarregado de negócios da Alemanha pede armistício e precipita a vitória republicana |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=1 September 2010}} The German diplomat, accompanied by a man with a white flag, went to the Rotunda to discuss the armistice with the revolutionaries. The latter, however, at the sight of the white flag, mistakenly thought that the king's forces were surrendering, prompting them to join with crowds a celebration of the new republic. In the square, Machado Santos initially refused to accept the armistice, but eventually accepted it after the insistence of the diplomat. Then, seeing the massive popular support for the revolution in the streets, he recklessly went to the headquarters, accompanied by many of the people and several officers who left the position in the Rotunda. The situation in Rossio, with the pouring of the populace onto the streets, was very confusing but advantageous to the republicans, given the obvious public support. Machado Santos spoke to General Gorjão Henriques and invited him to keep the role of division commander, but he refused. António Carvalhal, known to be a republican sympathiser, then received command. Soon afterwards, at 9 o'clock in the morning, the Republic was proclaimed by [[José Relvas]]{{cite web |url=http://ww1.rtp.pt/noticias/?t=Jose-Relvas-proclamou-a-Republica-a-5-de-Outubro-de-1910.rtp&headline=20&visual=9&tm=8&article=284424 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120629085041/http://ww1.rtp.pt/noticias/?t=Jose-Relvas-proclamou-a-Republica-a-5-de-Outubro-de-1910.rtp&headline=20&visual=9&tm=8&article=284424 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=29 June 2012 |title=José Relvas proclamou a República a 5 de Outubro de 1910 |publisher=RTP |accessdate=31 August 2010 }} from the balcony of the [[Lisbon City Hall]]. A provisional government was then nominated, presided by members of the [[Portuguese Republican Party]], with the mandate to govern the nation until a new constitution was approved. The revolution caused dozens of casualties. The exact number is unknown, but it is recognised that as of 6 October, 37 people killed in the revolution were registered in the morgue. Several injured turned up at the hospitals, some of whom later died. For example, out of 78 injured victims checked into Hospital de São José, 14 died in the following days.{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00725 |title= Vítimas da revolução |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=1 September 2010}} ===The royal family's exile=== [[File:Ericeira - Praia dos pescadores.JPG|thumb|upright=1.2|''The Praia dos Pescadores'' in [[Ericeira]], location of the departure of King Manuel II after 5 October 1910 revolution.]] In Mafra, on the morning of 5 October, the king was looking for a way to reach Porto, an action that would be very difficult to carry out due to the almost non-existence of an escort and the innumerable revolutionary hubs spread throughout the country. At around midday the [[President of the Municipal Chamber]] of [[Mafra, Portugal|Mafra]] received a message from the new [[Civil Government|civil governor]] ordering the switching to a republican flag. Soon afterwards the commander of the Infantry School also received a [[telegram]] from his new commander informing him of the current political situation. The position of the royal family was becoming unsustainable. The solution appeared when news arrived that the royal yacht ''Amélia'' had anchored nearby, in [[Ericeira]]. By 2am the yacht had collected from Cascais Citadel the king's uncle and heir to the throne, D. Afonso, and knowing that the king was in Mafra, had moved to Ericeira, as it was the closest anchorage. D. Manuel II, knowing that with the proclamation of the Republic he would be imprisoned, decided to go to Porto. The royal family and some company departed for Ericeira where, by means of two fishing ships and in the presence of curious civilians, they embarked on the royal yacht.{{cite web |url=http://www.mafra.net/ericeira/index.php |title=A juga do rei |publisher=''Guia do concelho de Mafra'' |accessdate=31 August 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529063343/http://www.mafra.net/ericeira/index.php |archive-date=29 May 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Once on board, the king wrote to the prime minister: {{quote|My dear Teixeira de Sousa, forced by the circumstances I find myself obliged to embark on the royal yacht "Amélia". I'm Portuguese and will always be. I have the conviction of having always fulfilled my duties as King in all the circumstances and of having put my heart and my life on the service to the Country. I hope that it, convinced of my rights and my dedication, will recognise this! Viva Portugal! Give this letter all the publicity you can. |D. Manuel II{{cite book|url= |first=Rocha |last=Martins |title=op. cit.|pages=583}}}} After ensuring that the letter would reach its destination, the king announced that he wanted to go to Porto. He met with an advisory council, the officers on board and part of the escort. ''Amélia's'' Captain João Agnelo Velez Caldeira Castelo Branco and Chief Officer João Jorge Moreira de Sá opposed the opinion of the monarch, claiming that if Porto turned them away, they would not have enough fuel to reach a different anchorage. Despite the insistence of D. Manuel II, the Chief Officer argued that they carried on board the whole royal family, so his main duty was to protect their lives. In the end, the chosen port was [[Gibraltar]]. Once there, the king found out that Porto had also joined the republican cause. D. Manuel sent orders that the ship, being legally the Portuguese State's property, be returned to Lisbon. The deposed king would live out the rest of his life in exile.{{cite book|url= |first=Joaquim Veríssimo |last=Serrão |title=História de Portugal: A Primeira República (1910–1926) |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisbon |publisher=Editorial Verbo |year=1997 |pages=39 |volume=IX |id=}} ==The first steps of the Republic== ===Performance of the Provisional Government=== [[File:Portuguese Provisional Government, 1910.jpg|upright=1.3|thumb|Portuguese Provisional Government, 1910]] On 6 October 1910, newspaper ''Diário do Governo'' announced: "To the Portuguese people —Constitution of the Provisional Government of the Republic — Today, 5 October 1910, at eleven o'clock in the morning, was proclaimed the Portuguese Republic in the grand hall of the Palaces of Lisbon Municipality, after the end of the National Revolution movement. The Provisional Government was constituted immediately: Presidency, Dr Joaquim Teófilo Braga. Interior, Dr. António José de Almeida. Justice, Dr. Afonso Costa. Treasure, Basílio Teles. War, António Xavier Correia Barreto. Navy, Amaro Justiniano de Azevedo Gomes. Foreign, Dr. Bernardino Luís Machado Guimarães. Public Works, Dr. António Luís Gomes."''Diário do Governo'' de 6 de outubro de 1910, cit. in David Ferreira, "Governo Provisório Republicano" in ''Dicionário de História de Portugal'', direcção de Joel Serrão. Porto, Livraria Figueirinhas, 1985, vol. III, p. 142. By decree on 8 October, the Provisional Government determined the new names of the ministries, with the most important changes being made to the ministries of ''the Kingdom'', ''Treasure'' and ''Public Works'', which were renamed ministries of ''Interior'', ''Finances'' and ''Development''.{{cite web|url=http://www.iscsp.utl.pt/~cepp/governos_portugueses/i_republica/g._provisorio_1910-1911.htm|title=Governo Provisório: de 5 de Outubro de 1910 a 3 September1911. 334 dias|publisher=Instituto Superior de Ciências Sociais e Políticas – Universidade Técnica de Lisboa|accessdate=31 August 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110306064530/http://www.iscsp.utl.pt/~cepp/governos_portugueses/i_republica/g._provisorio_1910-1911.htm|archive-date=6 March 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} However, [[Basílio Teles]] refused the position and, on the 12th, it was given to [[José Relvas]].Teófilo Braga, em entrevista ao jornal ''Dia'' de 2 de abril de 1913, referiu: "Esse sujeito [José Relvas], logo nos primeiros dias da revolução apresentou-se-nos no conselho de ministros e disse: 'Como o Basílio Teles não vem para as finanças, eu queria ficar no lugar dele.' Eu fiquei mesmo parado, a olhar para o Bernardino [Machado], pasmado do impudor. [...] Mas o homem depois tornou-se a impor [...], e ficou ministro das Finanças" in Carlos Consiglieri (org). ''Teófilo Braga e os republicanos''. Lisboa, Vega, 1987 On 22 November, [[Manuel de Brito Camacho|Brito Camacho]] entered government after the departure of António Luís Gomes, appointed Portuguese ambassador in [[Rio de Janeiro]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=00640 |title=Proclamação da República nos Paços do Concelho de Lisboa e anúncio do Governo Provisório |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=31 August 2010}} {{Rquote|right|The ministers [of the Provisional Government], inspired by a high sense of patriotism, always sought to reflect in their actions the highest and most pressing aspirations of the old Republican Party, in terms of reconciling the permanent interests of society with the new order of things, inevitably derived from the revolution.|[[Teófilo Braga]]|21-06-1911Teófilo Braga discursando perante a Assembleia Nacional Constituinte, cit. in David Ferreira, "Governo Provisório Republicano" in ''Dicionário de História de Portugal'', direcção de Joel Serrão. Porto, Livraria Figueirinhas, 1985, vol. III, p. 144.}} During its time of power, the Provisional Government took a series of important measures that had long-lasting effects. To calm tempers and make reparations with the victims of the monarchy, a broad amnesty was granted for crimes against the security of the State, against religion, of disobedience, of forbidden weaponry usage, etc.{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=035024 |title=Amnistia |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=1 September 2010}} The [[Catholic Church]] resented the measures taken by the Provisional Government. Among these were the expulsion of the [[Society of Jesus]] and other [[religious order]]s of the [[Regular clergy]], the closure of [[convent]]s, the prohibition of religious teaching in schools, the abolition of the religious oath in civil ceremonies and a [[Laïcité|secularisation]] of the State by the separation of Church and State. Divorce was institutionalised,{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=035023 |title=Promulgada a Lei do Divórcio |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=1 September 2010}} as were the legality of [[civil marriage]], the equality of the marriage rights of men and women, the legal regulation of "[[Legitimacy (family law)|natural children]]";{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=035004 |title=Leis da Família |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=31 August 2010}} the protection of [[childhood]] and [[old age]], the reformulation of the [[News media|Press]] laws, the elimination of [[Royal and noble ranks|royal and noble ranks and titles]] and the acknowledgment of right to strike action.{{cite web |url=http://www.fmsoares.pt/aeb/crono/id?id=035026 |title=Direito à greve |publisher=Fundação Mário Soares |accessdate=31 August 2010}} The Provisional Government also opted for the dissolution of the then [[National Republican Guard (Portugal)#Municipal Guard, 1834|municipal guards]] of [[Lisbon]] and Porto, creating instead a new public body of defence an order, the [[National Republican Guard (Portugal)|National Republican Guard]]. For the [[Portuguese Empire|colonies]], new legislation was created in order to grant autonomy to overseas territories, an essential condition for their development. The [[national symbol]]s were modified – the [[Flag of Portugal|flag]] and the [[national anthem]] —, a new monetary unit was adopted – the ''[[Portuguese escudo|escudo]]'', equivalent to a thousand ''[[Portuguese real|réis]]''{{cite book|url= |first=António Miguel |last=Trigueiros |title=A grande história do escudo português |language=Portuguese |edition= |location=Lisbon |publisher=Colecções Philae |year=2003 |pages=444 |volume= |id=}} – and even the [[Portuguese orthography]] was simplified and appropriately regulated through the Orthographic Reform of 1911.{{cite web |url=http://www.publico.clix.pt/Sociedade/uma-revolucao-democratica-ou-a-vitoria-de-extremistas_1420605?all=1 |title=Uma revolução democrática ou a vitória de extremistas? |publisher=''Público'' |accessdate=31 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809221707/http://www.publico.clix.pt/Sociedade/uma-revolucao-democratica-ou-a-vitoria-de-extremistas_1420605?all=1 |archivedate=9 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }} The Provisional Government enjoyed extensive power until the official launch of the National Constituting Assembly on 19 June 1911, following the election of 28 May of the same year.{{cite web |url=http://www.iscsp.utl.pt/~cepp/eleicoes_portuguesas/1911._ac.htm |title=Eleições de 1911 (28 de Maio) |publisher=Instituto Superior de Ciências Sociais e Políticas – Universidade Técnica de Lisboa |accessdate=31 August 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612053028/http://www.iscsp.utl.pt/~cepp/eleicoes_portuguesas/1911._ac.htm |archive-date=12 June 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} At that time, the president of the Provisional Government, Teófilo Braga, handed over to the National Constituting Assembly the powers he had received on 5 October 1910. Nevertheless, the Assembly approved with acclaim the proposal presented by their president, Anselmo Braamcamp Freire to the congress: "The National Constituting Assembly confirms, until future deliberation, the functions of the Executive Power to the Provisional Government of the Republic". Two months later, with the approval of the [[Political Constitution of the Portuguese Republic]] and the election of the first [[President of Portugal|constitutional president of the Republic]] – [[Manuel de Arriaga]] – on 24 August, the Provisional Government presented its resignation, which was accepted by the president of the republic on 3 September 1911, marking the end of a government term of more than 10 months{{cite book|first=Joaquim Veríssimo |last=Serrão |title=op. cit. |pages=141 }} and the beginning of the [[First Portuguese Republic]]. ===Modification of national symbols=== With the establishment of the Republic, the [[national symbols]] were modified. By a Provisional Government decree dated 15 October 1910, a committee was appointed to design the new symbols.{{cite web|url=http://www.presidencia.pt/?idc=44|title=Bandeira Nacional|publisher=Página Oficial da Presidência da República Portuguesa |accessdate=27 August 2010}} The modification of national symbols, according to historian Nuno Severiano Teixeira, emerged from the difficulty that republicans faced with representing the Republic: {{Cquote |In a monarchy the king has a physical body and is therefore a recognisable person, recognised by citizens. But a republic is an abstract idea. |author=Nuno Severiano Teixeira |source={{cite web|url=http://jornal.publico.pt/noticia/25-08-2010/um-busto-e-um-hino-consensuais--e-uma-bandeira-polemica-20050890.htm |title=Um busto e um hino consensuais – e uma bandeira polémica |publisher=''Público'' |accessdate=27 August 2010}}}} ====The flag==== [[File:Portugal flag (1).jpg|thumb|Flag of the Portuguese Republic.]] {{Main|Flag of Portugal}} In relation to the flag, there were two inclinations: one of keeping the blue and white colours, traditional of Portuguese flags, and another of using "more republican" colours: green and red. The committee's proposal suffered several alterations, with the final design being rectangular, with the first two fifths closest to the flagpole to be green, and the three remaining fifths, red.{{cite web|url=http://www.portugal.gov.pt/PT/GC17/PORTUGAL/SIMBOLOSNACIONAIS/EVOLUCAODABANDEIRANACIONAL/Pages/BandeiraNacional_Evolucao.aspx |title=Evolução da bandeira nacional |publisher=Arquivo Histórico do Governo de Portugal |accessdate=1 September 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.tuvalkin.web.pt/terravista/guincho/1421/bandeira/pt.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061011014244/http://www.tuvalkin.web.pt/terravista/guincho/1421/bandeira/pt.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 October 2006 |author=António Martins |title=Bandeira de Portugal |publisher=www.tuvalkin.web.pt |accessdate=1 September 2010 }} Green was chosen because it was considered the "colour of hope", while red was chosen as a "combative, hot, virile" colour.{{cite web|url=http://www.portugal.gov.pt/PT/GC17/PORTUGAL/SIMBOLOSNACIONAIS/BANDEIRANACIONAL/Pages/BandeiraNacional.aspx |title=Bandeira Nacional |publisher=Arquivo Histórico do Governo de Portugal |accessdate=1 September 2010}} The project of the flag was approved by the Provisional Government by vote on 19 November 1910. On 1 December was celebrated the Feast of the Flag in front of the Municipal Chamber of Lisbon.{{cite web|url=http://www.republica2010.com/instituicoes/instituicoes_simbolos.php|title=Símbolos da República|publisher=Almanaque da República|accessdate=27 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002115430/http://www.republica2010.com/instituicoes/instituicoes_simbolos.php|archivedate=2 October 2010|df=dmy-all}} The National Constituting Assembly promulgated the adoption of the flag on 19 June 1911.{{cite web|url=http://www.portugal.gov.pt/PT/GC17/PORTUGAL/SIMBOLOSNACIONAIS/DECRETOQUEAPROVAABANDEIRANACIONAL/Pages/Decreto_Bandeira_Nacional.aspx |title=Decreto que aprova a Bandeira Nacional |publisher=Arquivo Histórico do Governo de Portugal |accessdate=1 September 2010}} ====The national anthem==== On 19 June 1911 the National Constitutional Assembly proclaimed ''[[A Portuguesa]]'' as the [[national anthem]],{{cite web |url=http://debates.parlamento.pt/page.aspx?cid=r1.c1911 |title=Diário da Assembleia Nacional Constituinte – 1911 |publisher=Assembleia da República |accessdate=31 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090520202420/http://debates.parlamento.pt/page.aspx?cid=r1.c1911 |archivedate=20 May 2009 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.presidencia.pt/archive/doc/19110619.pdf |title=Decreto da Assembleia Nacional Constituinte de 19 de Junho |date=19 June 1911 |publisher=Página Oficial da Presidência da República Portuguesa |accessdate=26 September 2010}} replacing the old anthem ''[[O Hino da Carta|Hymno da Carta]]'' in use since May 1834, and its status as national symbol was included in the new constitution.
